topic.title: Abstract

body.p: The Segmentation and Re-assembly (SAR / OPSA) subsystem components perform rate capture and recovery, and ODUk segmentation and reassembly operations for OTN data transmitted and received over the Interlaken interface.

The OPSA components performs the rate capture and recovery functions, supporting an aggregate 600G of bandwidth and up to 190 independent traffic streams. The ingress rate is captured via ingress receive clock information from the SERDES and from justification control information received in the ODUk overhead. This enables rate capture of ingress OTUks from SERDES interfaces, demuxed ingress ODUks, ingress clients from SERDES interfaces, and clients demapped from ODUks. The OPSA components also recover/generate the egress rate, enabling timing control of egress OTUks/clients to SERDES interfaces. Timing control is also supported for egress muxed ODUks and clients mapped to ODUks.

Ingress rate capture and egress rate recovery PLL segments can be cascaded together to complete the rate adaptation functions required to fulfill the network operations defined in standards while meeting associated jitter and wander specifications.

The SAR components are responsible for the segmentation and reassembly of switched ODUk packets as defined by the OIF-OFP Implementation agreement. The standard defines the rate capture parameters used to encode the rate of ODUks in-band in the size of the packets transported across the switch fabric. Definition of the rate capture parameters for various rate ODUks permits interoperability of the ODUk packet streams segmented at the fabric ingress and reassembled at the fabric egress. The SAR components also support insertion of the OIF-OFP SAR header at the fabric ingress and processing and removal of the header at the SAR egress. The SAR header timestamp field is used to enable latency compensation of switched ODUk packet streams.
